title: Carlos Biasutto
text:
Carlos Biasutto (born 22 February 1946 in <a href="Buenos%20Aires">Buenos Aires</a>) is a former <a href="Argentina">Argentine</a> <a href="Association%20football">football</a> goalkeeper and manager.
Playing career.
Biasutto joined the youth team of <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Atlanta">Atlanta</a> in 1963 and made his official league debut on 12 September 1965 in a 1–1 home draw against Huracán. He went on to make 121 appearances in all competitions for Atlanta.
Biasutto joined <a href="Rosario%20Central">Rosario Central</a> in 1969 and made his debut in a 2–2 draw against his former club Atlanta on 11 May 1969. He was the reserve goalkeeper in the side that won the <a href="Nacional%20championship">Nacional championship</a> of <a href="Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20Argentina%201971%23Nacional%20Championship">1971</a> and the first team goalkeeper for <a href="Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20Argentina%201973%23Nacional%20Championship">Nacional 1973</a>. He played 20 games for Central in the <a href="Copa%20Libertadores">Copa Libertadores</a> tournaments of <a href="1972%20Copa%20Libertadores">1972</a>, <a href="1974%20Copa%20Libertadores">1974</a> and <a href="1975%20Copa%20Libertadores">1975</a>. After 189 league games for Central Biasutto left the club to join <a href="Boca%20Juniors">Boca Juniors</a> in 1975.
Biasutto played for Boca Juniors between 1975 and 1976, his debut for the club came in a 1–2 home defeat to fierce rivals River Plate on 21 September 1975. He went on to make 26 league appearances for Boca and was part of the team that won the <a href="Metropolitano%20championship">Metropolitano championship</a> in <a href="Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20Argentina%201976%23Metropolitano%20Championship">1976</a>.
Between 1977 and 1978, Biasutto played for the <a href="Colombia">Colombia</a>n side <a href="Millonarios">Millonarios</a>. In 1978, Biasutto returned to Argentina to play for <a href="Uni%C3%B3n%20de%20Santa%20Fe">Unión de Santa Fe</a> where he played until the end of the 1979 season, making 55 league appearances for the club.
In 1980, he joined <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Platense">Platense</a> where he played 247 league games making him the fourth most capped Platense player in the history of the club and the Platense player who made the most top flight appearances for the club. He is remembered as one of the great icons of the club.
Biasutto retired as a player in 1986 having amassed 656 <a href="Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20Argentina">Primera División</a> appearances, putting him in fourth place on the all time list behind <a href="Hugo%20Gatti">Hugo Gatti</a>, <a href="Carlos%20Fernando%20Navarro%20Montoya">Carlos Fernando Navarro Montoya</a> and <a href="Ricardo%20Bochini">Ricardo Bochini</a>.
Managerial career.
Following his retirement Biasutto became a fitness coach and eventually progressed to become a manager. He has had three stints as manager of <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Belgrano">Club Atlético Belgrano</a> and has also managed <a href="Atl%C3%A9tico%20de%20Rafaela">Atlético de Rafaela</a> in Argentina. He has had three stints as manager of <a href="Club%20Blooming">Blooming</a> in <a href="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> and has also managed <a href="Club%20Jorge%20Wilstermann">Wilstermann</a> and <a href="Club%20Aurora">Aurora</a> as well as <a href="FBC%20Melgar">Melgar</a> of <a href="Peru">Peru</a>.
